intro.p: In this problem, we'll consider line integrals of gradient vector fields.

content.p: Shown below is a gradient vector field \mathbf{F}(x,y) = \nabla h(x,y) and a contour plot of its scalar potential function h(x,y).

image.description: Gradient vector field with contour plot and curve from P to Q.

content.p: Use the plot to determine the value of \displaystyle\int_C \mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{r}, where C is the oriented curve from P{{p}} to Q{{q}} shown.
One of the two vector fields listed below is a gradient vector field.
Determine which of \mathbf{F} or \mathbf{G} is a gradient vector field.
For the one that is NOT a gradient vector field: Explain how you can tell that no scalar potential function exists.
For the one that IS a gradient vector field: Compute its line integral along the oriented line segment from A{{a}} to B{{b}}.

outtro.p: The gradient field is \mathbf{ {{grad}} }, since \mathbf{ {{ngrad}} } does not satisfy the screening test, i.e., \dfrac{\partial {{ngrad}}_2}{\partial x} - \dfrac{\partial {{ngrad}}_1}{\partial y} = {{scurl}} \neq 0.
The line integral \displaystyle\int_C \mathbf{ {{grad}} }\cdot d\mathbf{r} has the value {{deltaf}}.
